title: 110_hr6251
content: The Act is titled the "Responsible Federal Oil and Gas Lease Act" and pertains to the issuance of new leases. The Responsible Federal Oil and Gas Lease Act prohibits the issuance of new leases for oil and gas exploration unless the lessee has diligently developed the Federal lands or is actively producing oil or gas. The Secretary of the Interior is required to issue regulations regarding diligent development. The Secretary must define "diligently developed" within 180 days of the Act's enactment, with benchmarks for oil and gas production within 5 years of the lease term. Failure to comply results in civil penalties under the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982. The term "lessee" includes in this section. The term "lessee" includes any person or entity that controls, is controlled by, or is in common control with a lessee. SEC. 3. LEASE TERMS. Leases for Offshore Lands under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act are amended to have an initial period of 5 years, renewable for 1-year periods if production is occurring or progress is being made towards production. The rental for each additional period must be double the rate of the last year of the initial period. Leases for Onshore Lands under the Mineral Leasing Act have an initial period of 5 years, renewable for additional 1-year periods if oil or gas production is ongoing or progress is being made towards production. The Mineral Leasing Act for Acquired Lands allows for leases to be subject to a rental for additional periods at double the rate of the last year of the initial period. Leases issued under this section shall be for an initial period of 5 years, renewable for additional 1-year periods, subject to conditions. The rental for each additional period must be double the rate of the last year of the initial period.
